children.subject: Your guess is as good as mine, but for what it's worth, my guess is that all we can do is show up on the first day. I emailed Prof. Wainwright about trying to get in and he never replied, so that's my plan.
For those who took 189, should we simply review our 189 material? Or should we brush up on 134/126 and 110 stuff?

What I heard about the entrance exam last year was that it was all linear algebra and probability. So 126 and 110 is probably stronger background than 189, but for those who've taken 189 you'll probably at least have seen most of the material before.

Repeating my disclaimer: I'm not affiliated with the course in any way and am only speculating here.
Just show up to the class on the first day, or is there anywhere we need to express interest?

From schedule.berkeley.edu: 

COMPSCI C281A - Statistical Learning Theory 
27242
001-LEC
Regular
TuTh 9:30AM - 10:59AM
Valley Life Sciences 2060
Martin Wainwright
08/24/2016 - 12/09/2016
Notes: This is a combined section class
Hi there, what is the lecture room & time information for the course? Also, for those who took CS189, will the entrance exam be highly related to CS189 material?

history.content:
An email was sent out to stat majors about impacted grad classes and procedures for interested undergrads to attempt to enroll. One on the list was Stat 241A, aka CS 281A. I haven't been able to find this information anywhere accessible to EECS/CS majors, so I thought I'd share it here:

From Prof. Wainwright: "I won't be enrolling any undergrads in this class in advance. Over 50 have requested to be enrolled, and so we will need to have some sort of entrance exam in the first week to determine eligibility. You can let any undergrads who ask you know this policy." 

Go to the class, take the entrance exam and then see if you will be admitted. Have a back-up course.


Edit: To clarify, this is all the information I have and I am not affiliated with the course in any way. I just want to take it and was frustrated with how much effort it took to even find this.
history.subject: PSA: CS 281A Enrollment for Undergrads
